div1.p: Kellogg feels it is essential that Hench see the preliminary sketches before Cornwell begins the work on canvas.

div1.head: Letter from George A. Kellogg to Philip Showalter Hench, February 7, 1941
div1.p:
Dr. Finlay will appear standing in his laboratory near his working table, on which
can be seen his microscope, testing tubes, etc. He will have in his hands a recipient
containing mosquitoe larvae, showing the same to the members of the American Commi-
ssion who is grouped at the right side of the canvas. This group will be formed by
doctors Walter Read, Agramonte, Lazear and Carroll. The original size of the can-
vas will be two and one half meters high by 3 meters long.

Having sufficient information, we left our interviewer because Massaguer and Poseda
were waiting for him to go to a banquet at the Country Club.

Going to our office we were remembering the most remarkable details of Dr. Finlay's
work. In the year 1881 when for the first time the Cuban doctor proclaimed his
phathogenetic theory saying that the Stegomya Mosquitoe was the carrier of the yellow
fever, thus called because its main symptom is the jaundice.

At that time the epidemic had its root in the zone of the Mexican Gulf, propagating
later to the U.S. and Canada following the course of the San Lorenzo and Mississippi
rivers. The epidemy also spread to the South and to some countries of Occidental
Europe.

When Dr. Finlay offered his experiences to the Academy of Medical Sciences in
Havana, the scientific world was indifferent to his postulates. Insensible to this
indifference he continued his studies until the opportunity arrived when the civili-
zation gave him credit. When after innumerable sacrifices the independence of our
country was possible in 1900, the government of the United States, interested in
the extermination of this horrible evil, named a Commission for the substantiation
of Dr. Finlay's experiments. This Commission was integrated by another Cuban
doctor, Mr. Agramonte, and the Americans: Major Walter Reed, Lazear and James
Carroll.

With the cooperation of the modest Cuban sage and following faithfully his direc-
tions the Commission started to experiment with the Stegomya Fasciata a very black
type of mosquitoe with silver spots in the thorax, a very common mosquitoe in the
endemic area and above all in the poor sections and in stagnant waters.

Some of this especimen were taken and permitted to absorb the blood of patients
having yellow fever. Several days after those mosquitoes had bitten a number of
voluntary persons who heroically let themselves be innoculated with its virus, they
were hospitalized together with other persons who were not bitten by the mosquitoes
and being in perfect health. In those who were bitten the yellow fever developed,
but not in the others.

Thus Dr. Finlay's theory culminated in an all around success, making possible the
adoption of many prophylactic measures in order to end the yellow fever. Our country-
man gave all he had, he gave advices and materials of his own, and in spite of his
generosity, it was tried to take from him the primacy of his discovery.

Many publications giving news of this discovery tried to obscure Dr. Finlay's
achievement to the benefit of the Commission, and many times they gave to the latter
all the glory and credit, particularly the English Medical Biography and almost all
they encyclopedias.

The question of the vindication of Dr. Finlay's glory was discussed at the X Inter-
national Congress of Medical History held in Spain at the request of Drs. Rafael
Menocal and Sergio Garcia Marruz, representatives of the Havana University and the
Cuban government. The Congress recognized the right of the Cuban doctors and in one
of their conclusions accepted unanimously the declaration recognizing the priority
of Dr. Finlay to the discovery.
